content.intro:
Modern, vibrant, and festive, Casablanca is the economic capital of Morocco. Its dynamism, Art Deco architecture, and mild climate make it a choice destination.

Casablanca irresistibly evokes travel, sun, architecture, and, of course, commerce. The most European of the Moroccan cities is also the largest in the kingdom, boasting a population approaching five million. With its business appeal, Casablanca is always vibrant and continues to expand: the opening of the new fishing port, in early 2017, and the development of a technology park alongside a gleaming new infrastructure means that Greater Casablanca is on its way.

Though proud of its flourishing economy, Casablanca has not forgotten its soul and traditions. ‘Casa', as its residents call it, must be experienced on foot, neighbourhood by neighbourhood. At the centre of the city, its unique Art Deco and Neo-Moorish architecture has been preserved. Just up Mohammed V Avenue to the square of the same name are buildings and houses from the 1930s with their pure and elegant lines. Lose yourself in the streets, keep your eyes open, and let yourself be seduced by an abundance of marvellous architectural detail.

On the city's coastline, ​​Anfa offers a fine example of spectacular Art Deco houses while the Old Medina is faithful to traditional Morocco. In the same style, the Habous district is lively with artisans and merchants. Booksellers, antique dealers, and tailors have all set up shop here. The souks in Habous are the most famous in the city, especially those selling olives and spices.

To the west, towards the sea, is the commercial port opposite the ancient citadel. Exposed to the winds and tides, the divine Hassan II Mosque is unmistakable. This masterpiece took 10,000 artisans nearly six years to build. It is the zenith of Moroccan architectural art.

Explore the coastline with its beautiful beaches, sunny restaurants, and trendy bars. The terraces are divine at sunset, and are filled with Casablancans all weekend long. Later in the evening, the discos take over in this city that never sleeps.

And while you're on holiday in Casablanca, why not check out Essaouira and Agadir?

map.mapTitle: Our selection of must-see places in and around Casablanca

seoData.seoTitle: Travel Guide Casablanca  - Plan your trip to Casablanca with Travel by Air France
seoData.seoDescription: Stay in Casablanca: what to visit to Casablanca, where to stay, which restaurant to go? All information to prepare your holidays to Casablanca with Air France.

content.title: A Moroccan take on organic food at Organic Kitchen

introduction.small: First gourmet space dedicated to organic food in Casablanca, Organic Kitchen is a hybrid between a restaurant, a deli and a gourmet grocery shop.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A Moroccan take on organic food at Organic Kitchen

paragraphs.text:
At the heart of the Racine neighbourhood in Casablanca, Organic Kitchen bets on local and organic products from responsible farming. Vegan and healthy cooking aficionados often gather in this stripped-down space that recalls of the hygge, the Nordic trend of well-being. The restaurant's menu is adapted to all diets and offers dishes that put Moroccan culinary traditions in the spotlight, such as the Matesha Bla Kefta tajine, inspired from the regular kefta tajine but replacing minced beef with a vegetal counterpoint. Fine deli products are also displayed on shelves in a committed take on consumption: the organic quinoa is sourced from the first Moroccan farm for this product, the cider vinegar uses Moroccan apples that do not meet retail sector specifications… Nearby, a deli, a bakery and a greengrocer all sell organic and local products. Together, they make Organic Kitchen a must for anyone looking into a new way to consume.

Organic Kitchen
6-8, rue Ahmed El Mokri (former rue d'Auteuil)
20000 Casablanca

+212 522 94 37 75

www.organickitchen.ma ﻿

Menu: around 205 MAD

content.title: Honey, I packed up the kids!

introduction.small: Visiting the White City with your entire family? Casablanca is full of parks and attractions for your bright and energetic little angels.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Honey, I packed up the kids!

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of the city, the Sindibad spreads out over 32 hectares of green areas: games and attractions located in an ecological park entirely devoted to animals.
On a smaller scale, meet up at Art Nature and Bouskou Farm, which should please both young and old.
Southwest of Casablanca, Loupi Jungle provides secured entertaining facilities where you are sure to find magic and wonder.
A few kilometres away, The Crazy Park spreads over one hectare of fun and games for the whole family.
Finally, on the northwestern border of Casablanca, Adventureland offers activities that will stimulate children's imagination with huge attractions, video simulations, and an ice rink!
For a family culinary experience, try La Grange restaurant, near the Bouskoura forest, enjoy a pizza or paëlla and let the kids rush down nearby slides, tame farmhouse animals, or even ride poneys and sit in a horse-drawn carriage.
On the road to Dar Bouaaza, at Chez Marie-Jeanne, the vibe is different, here the restaurant business is a family affair. Watch at The Little Farm or Dream Village as your children play among rabbits, peacocks and little goats.

Parc Sindibad by Walibi
Corner of Boulevard de l'Océan Atlantique and Avenue du Golfe Arabique
20140 Casablanca

Tel : +212 522 79 68 62

http://parcsindibad.ma/

 

Ferme de Bouskou
Route Ouled Saleh Bouskoura
20140 Casablanca

Tel : +212 661 77 82 11

https://www.facebook.com/La-Ferme-de-Bouskou-1374950292832296/

Parc Loupi Jungle
Corner of Boulevard de l'Océan Atlantique and Avenue du Golfe Arabique
20140 Casablanca

Tel +212 522 90 06 07

www.loupiland.ma

 

Crazy Park
Route d'Azemmour, km 16
Oued Merzeg
Dar Bouazza

Tel : +212 522 29 05 07

http://crazypark.ma/

Adventureland
Corner of Boulevard de l'Océan et boulevard de Corniche
20140 Casablanca

Tel : +212 522 79 88 77

www.adventurelandmaroc.com

 

La Grange
Km 14 route de Bouskoura
27182 Bouskoura

Tel : +212 522 33 43 88

lagrange.ma

 

Chez Marie-Jeanne
PK 18 Douar Araba
Route d'Azemour
Dar Bouazza

Tel : +212 522 33 01 38

https://www.facebook.com/chezmariejeanne1/

content.title: Wellness and freedom at the Mövenpick Hotel Casablanca

introduction.small: In the heart of Casablanca's business district, the Mövenpick Hotel provides an ideal location and luxurious facility for the well-being of smitten guests.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Wellness and freedom at the Mövenpick Hotel Casablanca

paragraphs.text:
The modern and luxurious Mövenpick Hotel is for everyone: families, couples, business or solo travelers. Away from the old neighbouring medina buzzing with tourists, come stay in a large room outfitted with the latest technological amenities. For added relaxation, enjoy the hotel spa. Located on the 16th floor, it discreetly looks out at the urban life below. On the schedule: authentic treatments, traditional steam bath (hammam) or Moroccan exfoliation. You may also relax in the sumptuous swimming pool waiting for you on the roof.
If you are looking for a culinary treat, know that the Casablanca Café offers Mediterranean-inspired dishes daily – unless you prefer sitting at the sleek and welcoming bar. Finally, guests looking to work can arrange seminars, meetings and receptions in the fully equipped multipurpose rooms available to guests.

Mövenpick Hotel Casablanca
Avenue Hassan II
20070 Casablanca

Tel : +212 522 48 80 00

www.movenpick.com/hotel-casablanca

Chambre : à partir de 1 365 MAD

content.title: Al Mounia: all the flavours of Morocco

introduction.small: Traditional Moroccan cuisine, zellij tilework, shimmering lights, Moorish garden... this is a must for those looking for authentic Moroccan cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Al Mounia: all the flavours of Morocco

paragraphs.text:
In the city centre, close to the Art Deco district, a large Moroccan door in varnished wood opens onto a shaded patio. Wrought-iron tables invite you to take a seat and sip a mint tea under the old pear tree—but don't stop yet. Climb the front steps covered with white and blue zellij tiles and enter the typical Moroccan house.

Inside, the magic happens right away in both Moorish salons, decorated in carved stucco and tiles, and a painted wooden ceiling. The dinner is organised around small Moroccan tables, on benches covered with Berber fabric. To decide what to order, just sneak a peak at what your smiling, cheerful neighbours are eating. You can choose between dozens of delicious dishes with oriental flavours: lamb skewers, tagines, couscous, pastillas, briouats, koftaand other delicacies. It's definitely hard to choose from so many tempting offerings!

Al Mounia
36, boulevard de Paris
20000 Casablanca

+212 522 22 26 69

Menu: around 350 MAD

introduction.small: The ideal place to sample home-cooked Moroccan specialties that are delicious, fresh, and reasonably priced!

paragraphs.text:
Set in the Habous district, the fiefdom of the restaurant's owner, the Zayna offers 100% authentic Berber cuisine. Greeted by the smiling hostess, you will love this charming spot, which opens onto a room in oriental style and reflects the very best of Moroccan craftsmanship. Equally lovely is the small outdoor terrace, which swarms every day with regulars.

The menu of tasty dishes will awaken your taste buds. Start with the famous harira soup, some Moroccan salads, or the fish briouats. Continue with the grilled méchoui or a Berber tagine with seasonal vegetables. You could try the pigeon pastilla or the other specialties, such as boulfaf kebabs or free-range chicken with saffron. To finish, a fruit salad and some almond pastries, and a good Mlakkam tea. The atmosphere is so pleasant you'll find it difficult to leave. And when the bill comes, you will not lose your smile, as the prices are low.

Restaurant Zayna
Place Habous
73, rue Ibn Jaljal
20000 Casablanca

+212 522 54 25 96

www.facebook.com/Resto-Zayna-594218170628545

Menu: around 110 MAD

content.title: La Sqala: a Moorish café overlooking the sea

introduction.small: In the old fortress of a sultan, the café-restaurant La Sqala has a magical location. And its gourmet menu is full of nice surprises.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Sqala: a Moorish café overlooking the sea

paragraphs.text:
Facing the harbour and overlooking the medina, this fortified 18th-century stronghold is one of the last vestiges of Sultan Sidi Ben Abdellah, who transformed Casablanca. Completely restored, the fort is majestic. This seaside restaurant, with its Moorish facade of ochre and blue, makes you want to embark on an adventure. Two large cannons have been placed on either side of the entrance's sculptured door, and, inside, the decor is magical: a genuine Andalusian garden of oriental perfumes.

The French-Moroccan menu, worthy of the surroundings, is to be enjoyed on the shaded terrace or in the restaurant, which opens onto the exterior. The brunch and breakfast are delicious, as are the house specialties: tagine and grilled fish. During the day, there is nothing nicer than sitting under the shady fig tree, near the Andalusian fountain, sipping a fruit cocktail or a mint tea. And the service? Impeccable.

La Sqala
Boulevard des Almohades
20250 Casablanca

+212 522 26 09 60

restopro.ma/sqala/

Menu: around 180 MAD

content.title: Le Doge: an Oriental boutique hotel

introduction.small: In a period building nestled in the heart of the Art Deco district, this oriental boutique hotel and spa is a gem to be sweetly savoured.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Doge: an Oriental boutique hotel

paragraphs.text:
Le Doge is a 1930s architectural jewel. From the exterior facade to the interior ornamentation, nothing seems to have changed since the day it was built—its spell remains unbroken. The entrance is a tribute to the decorative arts, from marble floor and sublime staircase to the brass-plated scrollwork and macassar wood. In the spirit of artist Tamara de Lempicka, a large painting of a ‘sleeping beauty' presides over red velvet banquette seats.

There are 16 rooms and suites, each inspired by a legendary artist or writer.
The ‘Colette' room sports a variety of wall hangings while the ‘Hemingway' features leather, wood, and animal motifs. The ‘Charlie Chaplin' is distinguished by its beige and black stripes, classic furniture, and marbled bathroom. ‘Josephine Baker', ‘Coco Chanel', ‘Humphrey Bogart', ‘Modigliani'… the spacious rooms inspire daydreams of bygone days and famous personages. If you get a sudden urge to read, indulge in a novel in the gilded wood-panelled library in the first floor lounge. It's open all day, as is the rooftop terrace, looking out onto the rooftops of Casa.

Hôtel & Spa Le Doge
9, rue du Dr Veyre
20250 Casablanca

+212 522 46 78 00

www.hotelledoge.com

Rooms: from 1,607 MAD

introduction.small: An iconic address for over 40 years, Le Cabestan is always a good bet. Whether for lunch, dinner, or drinks, the atmosphere is in full swing from morning to night.

paragraphs.text:
Le Cabestan—or‘Cab' as the regulars like to call it—is known to all Casablancans. This is one of the city's hotspots. Nestled on the Corniche near the Hassan II Mosque and the lighthouse, this design restaurant offers spectacular ocean views. It is the perfect place for business lunches, dinners with friends, a drink at the lounge bar before dinner, or, after 11:00 p.m., dancing.

On the menu, southern French cuisine rules, with an emphasis on bounty from the sea: fish and seafood are served in all forms under the stewardship of chef Fabien Caboy. Steamed crayfish ravioli or bisque and lobster meat with foie gras are just some of the highlights, along with swordfish fillet, monkfish papillote, and duck breast. The choice is agonizingly hard... Inside or out, seats are hard to get, especially on weekends, so book in advance.

Cabestan
El Hank
90, boulevard de la Corniche
20000 Casablanca

+212 522 39 11 90

www.le-cabestan.com

Menu: around 470 MAD

content.title: Hassan II Mosque: a must-see masterpiece

introduction.small: The third largest mosque in the world, the Hassan II mosque majestically faces the sea. Adorned with tiles in geometric patterns, it is the work of the kingdom's best craftsmen.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hassan II Mosque: a must-see masterpiece

paragraphs.text:
Opened 30 August 1993 by King Hassan II, this masterpiece is an architectural feat. Its enormous size, technology, and splendour required six years of construction, and a whole year for the sumptuous decorative work. More than 10,000 of the best artisans from Ouarzazate, Agadir, Fez, and Marrakech worked together to make the mosque into a beautifully sublime showcase of Moroccan craftsmanship. Enter the mosque from the esplanade to admire the minaret, more than 200 metres in height, as well as the titanium royal door. Inside, this vast place of worship accommodates up to 25,000 worshippers. From floor to ceiling, the decor is magical: heated marble travertine floors, hand-carved stucco walls, an open ceiling of carved cedar wood, not to mention the roof, weighing over 1,000 tonnes, which opens and closes automatically in a few seconds! The prayer hall, ablution rooms, and hammam are equally impressive. Note that visits are restricted Friday mornings.

Hassan II Mosque
20000 Casablanca

+212 522 22 03 34

www.mosquee-hassan2.com

content.title: Hotel Central in the heart of the medina

introduction.small: Near the Corniche and the train station at Casa-Port, this hotel in the Old Medina is known throughout the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Central in the heart of the medina

paragraphs.text:
A few minutes' walk from the Hassan II Mosque, this beautiful Art Deco building offers services much superior to many of its neighbours. The 32 rooms and five suites are comfortable, and equipped with bathrooms. Some have a lovely view of the garden square. The owners have focused on the room decor and friendly, brightly coloured public areas.

If you are in Casablanca for business, you will appreciate Wi-Fi in all the rooms and a business centre equipped with 20 computers with broadband connection that is open 24/7. There is also a dry-cleaning service, a restaurant, and a tearoom. At the end of the day, relax with a drink on the beautiful hotel terrace with its breathtaking view of Casablanca.

Hotel Central Casablanca
20, place Ahmad El Bidaoui
20300 Casablanca

+212 522 26 25 25

www.hotelcentralcasa.com/en

Rooms: from 340 MAD

content.title: Hyatt Regency Casablanca: the address of choice

introduction.small: At the heart of the city, the Hyatt is contemporary-classic and chic. Summer or winter, this is a Casablanca favourite.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hyatt Regency Casablanca: the address of choice

paragraphs.text:
Conveniently located in the business district, this five-star hotel offers a 360º view of the Old Medina, with its quaint colours, and the majestic Hassan II Mosque facing the sea. It was sumptuously renovated in 2009 and 2016, and the service remains impeccable. From morning to evening, the lobby bar is always full: velvet sofas await you. The decor is warm and welcoming with soft lighting and contemporary fireplaces.

There is the same level of comfort in the 255 rooms and 33 suites, which are decorated in beige and wood tones. And club service offers customised extras: members have a private space on the 8th floor for breakfast or working meetings, as well as in the various hotel restaurants. Café M serves French cuisine and Dar Beidaoffers traditional Moroccan dishes, while the poolside restaurant offers cosmopolitan informal dining. For those who love to party, the Black House discotheque is open until three in the morning.

Hyatt Regency Casablanca
Place des Nations Unies
20000 Casablanca

+212 522 43 12 34

www.hyatt.com

Rooms: from 1,680 MAD

content.title: The ancient Portuguese city of El Jadida

introduction.small: A true gem of military architecture, this fortified city is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and the best-preserved Portuguese city on the coast.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The ancient Portuguese city of El Jadida

paragraphs.text:
Located 90 kilometres from Casablanca, the city formerly called Mazagan became El Jadida in 1815. Built by Portuguese sailors in the 16th century, this stronghold was a prosperous city and the last refuge for the Portuguese before fleeing to Brazil in 1769. Many vestiges of this remarkably preserved city remain today, including four of the five original bastions, which you can explore via a walkway with superb views. The bastion of the Angel has a panoramic view of the city, the beaches, and the sea.

Visit the Chapel of the Inquisition, near the San Sebastian bastion, and the Portuguese cistern built in 1514. The latter is an underground room, supported by five rows of columns and illuminated by a central skylight. It is a magical setting, which has appeared in several films, including the famous Othello by Orson Welles. Finish your walk by heading to the new city. If you have time, go for a swim at SidiBouzid Beach.

El Jadida Tourism Office
Avenue Mohamed VI
24000 El Jadida

+212 523 35 25 07

www.ot-eljadida.com

content.title: The Slaoui Museum: a tribute to art lovers

introduction.small: The Abderrahman Slaoui Foundation Museum in Old Casablanca welcomes you in a 1940s Art Deco villa.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Slaoui Museum: a tribute to art lovers

paragraphs.text:
The first half of the collection, which consists mainly of Orientalist posters and antique Moroccan objects, is dedicated to travel. In the second half, the museum takes you into the feminine universe of perfumes, jewellery, and other accessories. There is also a valuable series of Berber and 19th-century gold ornaments crafted by the country's most talented master jewellers. And finally, there is an entire room dedicated to Mohammed Ben Ali R'bati, Morocco's first figurative painter. Besides the permanent exhibitions, two spaces are reserved for temporary events. At the end of your visit, take a break in the tearoom on the top floor.

The Abderrahman Slaoui Foundation Museum
12, rue du Parc
20070 Casablanca

+212 522 20 62 17

www.musee-as.ma

introduction.small: Built in the 1920s by the French, this ‘modern' medina reconciles traditional architecture and European comfort.

paragraphs.text:
In large shady arcades, shops and stalls offering every Moroccan craft from carpets, hammered copper, and colourful pottery to wood carvings and sculpted leather are lined up next to each other. You are in the lively neighbourhood of Habous: located in the southern part of the city, just behind the Royal Palace, this area was designed to resemble a traditional medina.
Respectful of Muslim styles and traditions, there are, of course, many places of worship, including the Mohammed V Mosque, plus various souks, several hammam steam-rooms, the kissaria (covered market) artisanal crafts mart… With its Provencal influences, Habous is an authentic small town full of arcades, pedestrian streets, and airy, welcoming squares. And there's plenty of market action: the souks selling olives and spices are the best in town. And don't forget Bennis, the best pastry shop in the country.

Habous
20250 Casablanca

content.title: The Four Seasons: a luxurious oasis on the sea

introduction.small: Opened in early 2016, this beachfront hotel quickly became the city's trendiest spot. It brings together beauty, luxury, and modernity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Four Seasons: a luxurious oasis on the sea

paragraphs.text:
On the coastline just minutes from Morocco Mall, the Four Seasons Hotel Casablanca is ideally located, facing the ocean yet close to the bustle of the city. The high-design building of wood and glass fits seamlessly into its surroundings, seeming to melt into its lush green gardens. The 186 rooms are spacious and elegantly decorated with a subtle Moroccan touch. They all have the same amazing view over the Atlantic and the famous, fully customisable Four Seasons bed.

Equally chic, the hotel's three lounge restaurants are always full: Blue boasts sumptuous decor and a VIP menu; the patio at Mint is the place to take in the glowing sunset and dine next to a crackling fire in the outdoor fireplace; poolside at Latitude 33 is the perfect place for a tasty snack. Rejuvenate in the most beautiful spa in Casablanca among stone and carved cedar wood under wrought-iron lanterns. The same attention to detail is reflected throughout the hotel. From the decor to the service, the illusion of living in a fairy tale is complete.

Four Seasons Hotel Casablanca
Boulevard de la Corniche
20050 Casablanca

+212 529 07 37 00

www.fourseasons.com/casablanca/

Rooms: from 2,380 MAD

content.title: Sofitel Casablanca: overlooking the White City

introduction.small: Downtown near the Mohammed V Square, Sofitel Casablanca Tour Blanche overlooks the city and its surroundings from a height of 24 floors.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sofitel Casablanca: overlooking the White City

paragraphs.text:
Opened in 2012, this hotel is elegantly appointed, fusing together elements of traditional French and Moroccan decor. The polished glass entrance, for example, is embellished with acanthus leaves and Berber motifs. The 171 cosy rooms are in mauve, ochre, and pink, warm Maghreb-accented colours. Equipped with the latest technologies, the rooms have an incredible view of the city skyline and ocean.

The spectacular penthouse on the 24th floor has a 260-square-metre patio with a private pool and a 360º view of Casablanca. The 600-square-metre Spa Carita is dedicated to wellness. Within its iridescent black-and-white tiled walls you can relax in the hammam and then indulge in a honey exfoliation. Finish off with delicious Oriental cuisine at Atelier restaurant or French food at Brasserie La Tour. A pure delight.

Sofitel Casablanca Tour Blanche
Rue Sidi Belyout
20000 Casablanca

+212 522 45 62 00

www.sofitel.com

Rooms: from 1,758 MAD

introduction.small: See another side of Casablanca: the wild landscape of the Corniche on the Atlantic Ocean is the place for long walks, sport, eating out, and breathing in the fresh air.

paragraphs.text: Surrounded by the sea, Casablanca is a beach town bustling with ice cream vendors, restaurants, nightclubs, and one of the most beautiful buildings in the country, the Hassan II Mosque. The Corniche, which stretches out over several kilometres, is a lively place, especially at weekends. Come here to stroll or jog along the Atlantic Ocean. Many restaurants, such as Le Petit Rocher and Le Cabestan are here, as are the Venezia Ice café and the Four Seasons hotel.  A portion of the Corniche—from the lighthouse to Morocco Mall and the Tahiti Beach Club—have been restored recently. Walk to Ain Diab Beach along a wide seaside promenade dotted with benches. Or go even further, to the island of the Marabout de Sidi Abderrahmane, where women perform fertility rituals at the tomb of a Muslim holy man. Here, as elsewhere, the traditions are still alive!

content.title: JM Suites Hotel: an apartment hotel that means business

introduction.small: Located in one of the best areas of the city, this cosy 22-suite hotel is equipped with the latest technology.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: JM Suites Hotel: an apartment hotel that means business

paragraphs.text:
Located in the middle of Casablanca, close to the business district and the Sacred Heart Cathedral, this boutique hotel was designed by architect Patrick Collier. The 22 contemporary-style suites are like real apartments, with a kitchenette, office area, terrace or balcony, and large bedroom with ensuite bathroom.

Popular with business travellers, it perfectly meets their needs with, in particular, a business centre. There is also a steam room, sauna, restaurant, and a terrace bar, James, which has the best-known rooftop in Casablanca. Located on the fifth floor and always busy, it has views of the Sacred Heart Cathedral, Wilaya Square and the magnificent Hassan II Mosque. Excellent value for money.

JM Suites Hotel
161, corner of Bd Rachidi
Dar-el-Beida
20070 Casablanca

+212 522 26 06 66

www.jmsuiteshotel.com

Rooms: from 982 MAD
